title: TobyMac's son, Truett McKeehan, made his rapping debut at 6 years old on his dad's album
text:
CLOSE

Toby McKeehan, professionally known as Christian artist TobyMac, plays with is son Truett, 8, in the backyard of their Franklin, Tenn. home on April 16, 2007. (Photo: Shelley Mays, The Tennessean)

By the time he was six years old, Truett McKeehan had a song on a gold album.

The Nashville rapper — who died Wednesday at age 21 — made his musical debut with his dad, Christian music star TobyMac, on his 2004 album "Welcome To Diverse City."

Fans got to hear McKeehan grow up, as he made appearances on five consecutive TobyMac albums, often with his own dedicated track, through age 16.

Over the last two years, McKeehan started to carve out his own career, releasing his latest self-produced single, "Eyes," in June.

"He expressed himself through the music he made," TobyMac wrote in a statement released Thursday.

"And by made I mean, written, recorded, produced, mixed, and designed the art. All of it. A true artist. His first show was a week ago, and it was nothing short of electric. Everyone felt it, everyone knew it. He could’ve easily taken the easy route and put music out when he was 12, 14, 16, even 18, but he always said he wanted to live some life and have something to say before he did it. He didn’t want to be a child star, he wanted to be a man with scars and a story to tell. I always admired, respected and encouraged that stand."

We've collected all of their collaborations below, plus the music video for "Eyes."

"TruDog: The Return" (2004)

"Hype Man (truDog '07)" (2007)

"LoudNClear (TruDog 10)" (2010)

"Mac Daddy (Tru's Reality)" (2012)

"Backseat Driver" (2015)

description: Fans got to hear McKeehan grow up, as he made appearances on five consecutive TobyMac albums — often with his own dedicated track — through age 16.
